subject: Re: [junit] Unit testing Exception classes
msgSnippet: ... It depends on intent. Is this behavior similar to using toString() to make my test failure messages more useful? or is it more interesting than that? I
messageBody:
Ilja Preuss wrote:
> junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:
> > Another common case you'll want to test is where you use more
> > type-specific constructors. For instance, a TimeException class might
> > have getTime() and setTime() methods, and constructors that take a
> > Date object as well as a string. These need to be tested.
> > Furthermore, if the detail message is changed depending on the extra
> > typed data you passed in, then getMessage(), printStackTrace() and
> > some other dependent methods may need to be tested as well.
>
> I'm not sure I would test those, simply because it's not critical for the
> functioning of the software, but "just" debugging information. Might just be
> me being lazy, though.

It depends on intent. Is this behavior similar to using toString() to
make my test failure messages more useful? or is it more interesting
than that?

I almost always implement toString() as

BeanUtils.describe(this).toString()

so it's almost too simple to break. Nothing can ever be null there. The
only thing I could get wrong is not having getX() methods for the bean
properties I'm interested in. I find myself only wanting to toString()
Java bean type classes.
